Peaks

Source: R/AllGenerics.R, R/peaks.R
peaks.Rd

Finds local maxima in sequential data.

findPeaks(object, ...)

fitPeaks(object, peaks, ...)

# S4 method for GammaSpectrum
findPeaks(object, method = c("MAD"), SNR = 2,
  span = NULL, ...)

# S4 method for GammaSpectrum,numeric
fitPeaks(object, peaks, bounds = NULL,
  ...)

# S4 method for PeakPosition,missing
fitPeaks(object, bounds = NULL, ...)

Arguments

object

An object of class GammaSpectrum or PeakPosition.
...

Extra parameters passed to estimateBaseline.
peaks

A numeric vector giving the starting peak postions for the nonlinear model fitting (see below).
method

A character string specifying the methode to be used for background noise estimation (see below).
SNR

An integer giving the signal-to-noise-ratio for peak detection (see below).
span

An integer giving the half window size (in number of chanels). If NULL, 5% of the number of chanels is used as the half window size.
bounds

A numeric vector giving the parameters bounds (in percent), replicated to be of length three (see below). If NULL (the default), all parameters are assumed to be unconstrained.

Value

findPeaks returns an object of class PeakPosition.

fitPeaks returns an object of class PeakModel.

Peak detection

A local maximum has to be the highest one in the given window and has to be higher than \(SNR \times noise\) to be recognized as peak.

Peak fitting

TODO

See also

Other signal processing: integrateSignal, processBaseline, smooth

Examples

# Import a Canberra CNF file
spc_file <- system.file("extdata/test_CNF.cnf", package = "gamma")
spectrum <- read(spc_file, skip = TRUE)

# Find peaks
(peaks <- findPeaks(spectrum))
#> 5 peaks were detected:
#>         chanel    energy counts       rate
#> peak #1     86  248.1211   2376 0.70180828
#> peak #2    210  621.9622    840 0.24811404
#> peak #3    316  943.0964    297 0.08772603
#> peak #4    496 1491.7134    910 0.26879021
#> peak #5    876 2663.5239    110 0.03249112
plot(peaks)

# Fit peaks
## Using previously detected peaks
(fit1 <- fitPeaks(peaks))
#> 5 peaks were estimated:
#>              mean        sd     height
#> peak #1  85.80644  2.685600 2447.41272
#> peak #2 208.04992  7.068457  816.19416
#> peak #3 320.70330 15.149748  253.64254
#> peak #4 494.86226  9.744063  877.72082
#> peak #5 877.18589 14.328315   98.54375
plot(fit1)
## Specifying starting positions
(fit2 <- fitPeaks(spectrum, peaks = c(86, 496, 876)))
#> 3 peaks were estimated:
#>              mean        sd     height
#> peak #1  85.80644  2.685600 2447.41272
#> peak #2 494.86226  9.744063  877.72082
#> peak #3 877.18589 14.328315   98.54375
plot(fit2)
